column2: Divisions: Experts weigh in on FDA's decision to "pause" Johnson & Johnson vaccine
column5: Following up on Edâ€™s post earlier about todayâ€™s big news the divide between doctors/scientists on the one hand and average joes like me about the wisdom of pausing distribution of J&J is even starker than usual on social media. There are plenty of experts who think the caution is prudent and justified. There are hardly any laymen who agree. Although interestingly itâ€™s not uniform among the pros. Even some of them think the FDAâ€™s move was shortsighted. Those in favor of pausing include some of the most closely public-health experts on Twitter: Important breaking news US govt calling for a pause of the J&J vaccine after a small number of people develop a very rare blood clot. While unfortunate its the right step. Central to vaccination success is ensuring people have confidence they are safehttps://t.co/pnyNnbvHjm â€” Ashish K. Jha MD MPH (@ashishkjha) April 13 2021  I know lots of folks think this will cause more vaccine hesitancy â€” and more harm than good. I'm honestly not so sure My sense is confidence comes from people believing that we have a vigorous system that takes adverse events seriously. We do.  This is how it works. â€” Ashish K. Jha MD MPH (@ashishkjha) April 13 2021  ğŸ‘‡ğŸ»Exactly.6 cases out of 7 million doses. This is an extremely rare (less than 1 in a million) â€œsafety signal.â€ Its normal for FDA to investigate and to pause while it does out of caution. I got the J&J vaccine 8 days ago. Iâ€™m not losing sleep over this. https://t.co/J56BtGSCG3 â€” Dr. Angela Rasmussen (@angie_rasmussen) April 13 2021  â€“ The risk-benefit profile depends upon age likely sex and population incidenceâ€“ As weâ€™ve seen in Europe one path forward may be vaccination policies that vary by age sexâ€“ Understanding the causal mechanism may help us develop targeted policies and potential treatments2/2 â€” Natalie E. Dean PhD (@nataliexdean) April 13 2021  Itâ€™s not a long â€œpauseâ€ either. The FDA will meet tomorrow about it. â€œ[I]f you want vaccine-hesitant people to believe no corners were cut you canâ€™t then go around very obviously cutting cornersâ€ said one Twitter pal in support of the delay. Which is a defensible argument: Imagine if the FDA simply said â€œthe clots are super-rare weâ€™re sure itâ€™s fineâ€ without any further investigation â€” and then a dozen more clots were reported in J&J recipients. What would the publicâ€™s view of that vaccine be then? Other doctors think the FDAâ€™s being overcautious particularly given the urgency of getting people vaccinated ASAP before we endure another national wave. The risk of blood clots from vaccination canâ€™t be taken in isolation; it needs to be compared to two other risks. First whatâ€™s the risk of a person developing clots for â€œnormalâ€ non-vax reasons? And second whatâ€™s the risk of an unvaccinated person contracting COVID and either dying from it or developing COVID-related blood clots? Dr. Megan Ranney ran the numbers: 4. Letâ€™s compare: Which is higher? â€” Megan Ranney MD MPH ğŸ—½ (@meganranney) April 13 2021  6. What is INDUBITABLY true right now is that #covid19 cases are rising in the US and across the world and the J&J vaccine is very very good at preventing disease / excellent at preventing severe disease and death. â€” Megan Ranney MD MPH ğŸ—½ (@meganranney) April 13 2021  Note the last point though. Many skeptics have cited the fact that there were only six clotting cases out of seven million doses making the odds literally one-in-a-million of this happening to a J&J recipient. (Slightly more actually.) But thatâ€™s only true if the risk is spread equally among all recipients which may not be the case. Thereâ€™s chatter today about the fact that all six patients were women and all of childbearing age. A friend speculated this morning to me that this may be a case of the vaccine interacting badly with birth control which seems plausible on its face as certain forms of contraception *do* increase the risk of blood clots. In which case it may be that J&J is perfectly safe for men and for older women â€” but a bit riskier than one-in-a-million for younger women. Especially since we donâ€™t know for sure how many clotting cases there are. Six have been confirmed but there may be more that went overlooked by doctors who treated clot patients recently because they werenâ€™t looking for a connection between clotting and J&Jâ€™s vaccine. Now theyâ€™ll be on the lookout. Thereâ€™s a massive third risk created by pausing J&J of course. Remember what happened to public trust in AstraZenecaâ€™s vaccine last month when European governments temporarily paused distribution due to clotting fears?  Inescapably some people who are on the fence about getting vaccinated will treat the FDAâ€™s â€œpauseâ€ as proof that the vaccines arenâ€™t safe and decide against getting their shot. And not just J&Jâ€™s vaccine maybe: The fact that super-ultra-rare blood clots werenâ€™t discovered during that companyâ€™s clinical trials will lead anti-vaxxers to make the leap that there may be super-ultra-rare side effects from the Pfizer and Moderna vaccines that are still undiscovered. (Although interestingly there wasnâ€™t much spillover to opinion about the other vaccines in the poll above due to doubts about AstraZeneca.) Anecdotal reports of newfound vaccine hesitancy are already circulating on social media: We've already heard from two friends this morning â€” unsolicited â€” that this J&J stoppage has convinced them the vaccines were rushed and can't be trusted. Heckuva job. â€” Tim Alberta (@TimAlberta) April 13 2021  The â€œpauseâ€ could theoretically save say five lives by preventing vax-related blood clots and cost a thousand lives by inadvertently convincing people who would otherwise have gotten vaccinated that the scientists really did â€œcut cornersâ€ in this process and their products canâ€™t be trusted. Thatâ€™s some trade. And thatâ€™s why laymen are so angry about todayâ€™s decision: For us the main consideration here is avoiding anything that might encourage vaccine hesitancy unless the data is compelling that thereâ€™s a meaningful risk of harm involved. And there isnâ€™t yet. Although doubtless the FDA would say â€œWell thatâ€™s why we need to pause and investigate.â€ Watch Scott Gottliebâ€™s characteristically balanced take this morning on CNBC. He urges people not to overreact but acknowledges that the decision comes with costs and not just increased vaccine hesitancy. Remember that the J&J vaccine is hardier than Pfizerâ€™s or Modernaâ€™s says Gottlieb and therefore was being eyed for deployment to more rural areas where the deep-freeze storage needed for the mRNA vaccines isnâ€™t as widely available. The fact that J&J is a single dose also made it better suited to rural residents who tend to be more vaccine-resistant than city-dwellers and need to travel longer distances to get their shots. With J&J temporarily paused the mRNA vaccines will now have to be sent to those rural areas instead. Can they be stored safely there? How many locals will balk at two doses? Itâ€™s a bad situation. "Let's start with what the FDA didn't do: they didn't revoke the EUA they didn't order this off the market. This was a requested pause which is an awkward regulatory step but it reflects a level of caution not to appear too forcefully here" says @ScottGottliebMD on $JNJ vaccine pic.twitter.com/42Fg8OX8Ra â€” Squawk Box (@SquawkCNBC) April 13 2021
